html:
FWOTD – 4 October 2014

Etymology 1[edit]

From ex- +‎ cadō (“fall”).

Alternative forms[edit]

  • excadō (Late Latin)
  • escadō, escaiō, eschadō (Mediaeval Latin)

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈek.ski.doː/, [ˈɛk.s̠kɪ.d̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈeks.t͡ʃi.do/, [ˈɛks.t͡ʃi.d̪ɔ]

Verb[edit]

excidō (present infinitive excidere, perfect active excidī); third conjugation, no passive, no supine stem

  2. I fall out, from or down, tumble to the ground, collapse, break down, drop
  3. I fall out or from involuntarily, slip out, escape
  4. I differ from someone's opinion, disagree with, dissent
  5. I am lost or forgotten, pass away, perish, disappear
  6. I lose myself, fail; faint, swoon
  7. I slip out or escape from memory
  8. (with ablative) I am deprived of, miss, fail to obtain, forfeit, lose
Conjugation[edit]

Related terms[edit]
  • accidō
  • cadō
  • concidō
  • dēcidō
  • excidium
  • incidō
  • intercidō
  • occidō
  • prōcidō
  • recidō
  • succidō

Etymology 2[edit]

From ex- +‎ caedō (“cut; strike”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ekˈskiː.doː/, [ɛkˈs̠kiː.d̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /eksˈt͡ʃi.do/, [ɛksˈt͡ʃiː.d̪ɔ]

Verb[edit]

excīdō (present infinitive excīdere, perfect active excīdī, supine excīsum); third conjugation

  2. I cut or hew out, off, or down
    excīdō virīlitātem ― I castrate, geld
  3. I raze, demolish, lay waste, destroy
  4. (figurative) I extirpate, remove, banish
  5. (in a quarry) I cut out, hollow out, excavate

  • French: exciser

References[edit]

  • excido in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • excido in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • a thing escapes, vanishes from the memory: aliquid excidit e memoria, effluit, excidit ex animo
    • the recollection of a thing has been entirely lost: memoria alicuius rei excidit, abiit, abolevit
    • no word escaped him: nullum verbum ex ore eius excidit (or simply ei)
  • excido in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Niermeyer, Jan Frederik (1976) , “excidentia, excidere”, in Mediae Latinitatis Lexicon Minus, Leiden, Boston: Brill, page 388/1
